This is my first foray into Django, and for that it was very good! Honestly I think it was a very good value, and I have nothing negative to say about John or his teaching style.
It's *definitely* fast-paced--a little too fast for a code-along imo, but I never felt like I was falling behind.

results.content:
This To-Do App course is short and sweet and you do get some very useful techniques and the basics of Django and setting up your development environment - and you get a working To Do list web application.  

I like John's style.  He is interesting without being too "academic" (i.e. diving into the weeds for an introductory course).  I like him saying "don't worry about this for now" to indicate what was important or not for this course.  

I've done a lot of programming in other languages.  I was learning Django about a year ago.  

Some suggestions:  
I would have liked this to be a little more "real world."  

At least show how to return the to do list items with the equivalent of a SQL ORDER BY addition to the main query.  This would have only added a few seconds to the overall course as follows:
def home(request):
	if request.method == 'POST':
		form = ListForm(request.POST or None)

		if form.is_valid():
			form.save()
			# Get the List objects in the default order.  
			# all_items = List.objects.all

			# Get all tasks ordered by the completed flag and the task's name.  
			all_items = List.objects.all().order_by('completed', 'item')

A more real world application would have two or three levels to the tasks to e.g. organize them by task type for e.g. shopping.  And, within a task's type, for a store shopping list, optionally add a task attribute for e.g. the food type so you can view tasks grouped by Produce, Meat, Dairy, Household Cleaners, etc.  This would have added time to the course but then we'd have a very useful general purpose app, out of the box.  Perhaps this is big enough to become its own course on working with a Django database with multiple linked tables, instead of just one table. 

The last steps are to add user validation and how to deploy to e.g. Heroku but these are separate courses that this course could refer to.  

One last suggestion:  The Bootstrap table used to list all the tasks needs tweaking to put the completed/not completed entries in a narrower cell with a image links instead of text.  I expect that you'd show the completed field in the first column and use a narrower delete image not the "Delete" text.  So this could be another course on customizing Bootstrap controls.
results.content_html:
This To-Do App course is short and sweet and you do get some very useful techniques and the basics of Django and setting up your development environment - and you get a working To Do list web application.

I like John's style. He is interesting without being too "academic" (i.e. diving into the weeds for an introductory course). I like him saying "don't worry about this for now" to indicate what was important or not for this course.

I've done a lot of programming in other languages. I was learning Django about a year ago.

Some suggestions:
I would have liked this to be a little more "real world."

At least show how to return the to do list items with the equivalent of a SQL ORDER BY addition to the main query. This would have only added a few seconds to the overall course as follows:
def home(request):
if request.method == 'POST':
form = ListForm(request.POST or None)

if form.is_valid():
form.save()
# Get the List objects in the default order.
# all_items = List.objects.all

# Get all tasks ordered by the completed flag and the task's name.
all_items = List.objects.all().order_by('completed', 'item')

A more real world application would have two or three levels to the tasks to e.g. organize them by task type for e.g. shopping. And, within a task's type, for a store shopping list, optionally add a task attribute for e.g. the food type so you can view tasks grouped by Produce, Meat, Dairy, Household Cleaners, etc. This would have added time to the course but then we'd have a very useful general purpose app, out of the box. Perhaps this is big enough to become its own course on working with a Django database with multiple linked tables, instead of just one table.

The last steps are to add user validation and how to deploy to e.g. Heroku but these are separate courses that this course could refer to.

One last suggestion: The Bootstrap table used to list all the tasks needs tweaking to put the completed/not completed entries in a narrower cell with a image links instead of text. I expect that you'd show the completed field in the first column and use a narrower delete image not the "Delete" text. So this could be another course on customizing Bootstrap controls.

results.content: Very good Python/Django course. I have taken 2 python masterclass courses that included Django 1 & 2 prior to taking this course. However, this course is by far better if you want to learn Django than the information presented in the masterclass courses. My only complaint is that the example project, apps, classes, and functions could be named more appropriately. For example, using the word "task" instead of "item". But, that's just nitpicky. Thumbs up!
results.content_html: Very good Python/Django course. I have taken 2 python masterclass courses that included Django 1 & 2 prior to taking this course. However, this course is by far better if you want to learn Django than the information presented in the masterclass courses. My only complaint is that the example project, apps, classes, and functions could be named more appropriately. For example, using the word "task" instead of "item". But, that's just nitpicky. Thumbs up!

results.content:
I must say the instructor is superb, friendly and teaching style is best. This is why I am giving a 5 star rating. I bought the course and I didn't stop till the end of the course.

I know it's short & sweet course so it cannot have everything, but I would love to see how to 'upload image/file' and 'how to send email' as 2 bonus lessons for the course.

Thank you and you John had done an excellent job. Keep teaching and good luck.

I recommend this course for all web developers.

Thank you

Zaheen

results.content: This course was short and to the point. The pace is good for me, as I am coming back to Django after a bit of a break (with not a whole lot of coding in the interim). My only slight criticism is that instructor has the habit of clearing / switching the screen rather quickly in some of the videos, so there can be some "blink and you've missed it" moments if you are trying to code along. That said, the content was great, and you can always rewind the video.

results.content: This class a well-designed beginner's intro to Django. John elder does a great job explaining and is also super quick in answering questions. 5 stars for that! results.content:
This course is the definition of 'crash-course'.  It's fast, quick-paced and gets you to your destination ASAP.

I have experience with MVC in ASP.Net, so following along was slightly easier since I already know the fundamentals of the MVC pattern.  

I think if I did not have that background, I would have been a bit lost since this course travels through each topic quickly.  I'd recommend having some MVC background first.

That being said, this course got me up and running with Django very quickly, which was the purpose of my purchasing the course - I need to learn Django.

I enjoyed the compactness of the course since I could take a break from whatever I was doing and jump into a video or two at a time without being bogged down with too much information.

results.content:
John Elder obviously knows his stuff.  The course was very fast paced and to the point.

My only wish is that he went slower.  I found myself constantly rewinding and replaying footage as I went between my instance of the programs and my notes.  In the end, I gave up on my own instance and notes and just watched and listened.

I think the course is excellent to get a quick feel for creating a website with python and django using the sublime editor.   Perhaps he has another course that would be more detailed and at a slower pace.

I do appreciate getting the very quick run down on building a site from start to finish.

results.content: This is the best class that I have taken on Django so far, and I highly recommend it. John is an engaging instructor and the length of the course was perfect for me. The To Do List is a great app to introduce Django, way better than the horrible Blog app that everyone else uses. The only reason why I didn't give Johns course a perfect score is because he codes super fast, and I constantly had to pause to catch what he had coded. I also didn't give him a perfect score because I would have liked a few slides or animations that explained some of the conceptual stuff behind Django. I have read book on programming Django and done a few Udemy course on Django, but it all didn't come together for me until I took this course. So stop reading this and buy the course.

results.content:
Straightforward, no mess.  This course is awesome. It gets straight to the point and is project based. I absolutely love it. I'm almost thru the course. The length of the course is great too. Thanks for putting this awesome course together.

Update:

Just finished the course.  Again, I am very pleased with this course. It got straight to the point and I finished it in a few days. I learned enough of Django to feel comfortable enough to start work on my projet (the whole reason why I enrolled in this course). I highly recommend this course, especially if you're like me and you want something that doesn't beat around the bush, is project based, and is fun.  Thanks, John!

response.content: Glad you enjoyed it! Thanks for the great review!
response.content_html: Glad you enjoyed it! Thanks for the great review!

results.content_html:
Straightforward, no mess. This course is awesome. It gets straight to the point and is project based. I absolutely love it. I'm almost thru the course. The length of the course is great too. Thanks for putting this awesome course together.

Update:

Just finished the course. Again, I am very pleased with this course. It got straight to the point and I finished it in a few days. I learned enough of Django to feel comfortable enough to start work on my projet (the whole reason why I enrolled in this course). I highly recommend this course, especially if you're like me and you want something that doesn't beat around the bush, is project based, and is fun. Thanks, John!

results.content:
I like that the instructor gets straight to the point, and at the same time explains 90% of his reasoning on WHY certain things are done this particular way.

The pace is relatively quick. I usually watch most of my Udemy videos on 1.75x ~ 2x speed, but John talks quick enough that I can barely keep up at 1.25x. On the up side, you won't be bored.

To get the most out of this course, students should probably have a decent understanding on Python. It'd be much harder to keep up with the course's pace (unless you're fine with mirroring what the instructor did without understanding why).

There's also a quick intro on Bootstrap, which I super appreciate as I'm still very new to Web developing and didn't know where to start with Bootstrap till this course.

The only 0.5 star I took off is for the multiple things that he noted "We will cover this later" but never actually gotten to. I would appreciate a link or some sort of resource pointing towards further reading on those particular items - but then again, this is a short course. I think it's understandable that they weren't covered. Otherwise, a great course!

To get the most out of this course, students should probably have a decent understanding on Python. It'd be much harder to keep up with the course's pace (unless you're fine with mirroring what the instructor did without understanding why).

There's also a quick intro on Bootstrap, which I super appreciate as I'm still very new to Web developing and didn't know where to start with Bootstrap till this course.

The only 0.5 star I took off is for the multiple things that he noted "We will cover this later" but never actually gotten to. results.content:
This gets to the point - fast! If you're concerned that you don't have the time to follow a full course on Django, then this is the one for you! Very clear, detailed and easy to follow. 

If, like me, you don't type at the speed of light, then the ability to slow the course down using the playback speed might be of use!  I found my self pausing a LOT! Especially in the latter stages when John stops typing and starts copy/pasting...
results.content_html:
This gets to the point - fast! If you're concerned that you don't have the time to follow a full course on Django, then this is the one for you! Very clear, detailed and easy to follow.

If, like me, you don't type at the speed of light, then the ability to slow the course down using the playback speed might be of use! I found my self pausing a LOT! Especially in the latter stages when John stops typing and starts copy/pasting...

results.content: Great Python Django class. The instructor explains everything in easy to understand details and codes right along with you. The project is fun and a great into into working with Django and Database work. A++ class
results.content_html: Great Python Django class. The instructor explains everything in easy to understand details and codes right along with you. The project is fun and a great into into working with Django and Database work. A++ class

results.content:
I loved this course and how John explains the code and the functionalities!
It's easy to understand, and the examples that he uses is based on his experience and day by day programming.
I recommend this tutorial to anyone that wants to learn Django :)

results.content: My first course & review on Udemy! Great short course on basics of Django and Python. Working on the course was a lot of fun and I found the instructor very engaging! Definitely learned basics about Web development, Django, etc.
